awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Correlating Molecular Structure and Activity in Boron-containing ODH Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
As the world population grows, the demand for consumer goods, which are made from building-block chemicals such as ethylene and propylene, increases. The project focuses on discovery of energy-efficient catalysts for the production of these chemical building-blocks from natural gas with minimal generation of undesired by-products such as carbon dioxide.  Preliminary studies by the investigators have shown exceptional promise of boron-containing catalysts, but deeper, atomic-level understanding is needed to further improve the catalyst performance and durability.  The project will utilize a combination of new catalyst synthesis protocols, state-of-the-art solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance imaging, and computational methods to obtain the needed atomic-level understanding, and use that insight to design improved catalysts.  The research will support U.S. clean-energy security through its potential for the efficient conversion of our nation's vast shale gas resources to value-added fuels and chemicals. 

Oxidative Dehydrogenation (ODH) of light alkanes is a promising alternative for the production of important chemical building blocks. However, despite decades of research, a highly selective catalyst has remained elusive, as over-oxidation is a facile and thermodynamically favored process. Recent studies by the lead investigator's group has demonstrated that boron-containing catalysts (hBN, BNNT, WB, among others) are highly selective catalysts for the ODH of light alkanes. For propane ODH, propylene selectivity as high as 80% can be obtained up to 20% conversion, compared to 60% propylene selectivity at 10% propane conversion for the state-of-the-art vanadium oxide-based catalyst. Given the recent discovery of this class of materials as ODH catalysts, there are many fundamental questions that need to be answered regarding the active sites and their formation. Controlled synthesis, state-of-the-art solid-state NMR (SSNMR) spectroscopy, and computational modelling will be utilized to gain insights into the catalytically active site(s) and build up a structure-performance relationship for boron-containing ODH catalysts. The work will contribute to a molecular-level understanding of a complex problem that is of industrial importance. Our multidisciplinary approach comprised of synthesis, SSNMR characterization, catalytic testing, and computational modelling will train the participating students to use information from a variety of fields to develop a detailed picture of a complex system. Additionally, the collaborative nature of this work will help the students grow as productive members of a research team. Beyond the targeted reactions, the study will be of value to the broader catalysis community because of the generalized catalytic insights and the methods developed for characterization of heterogeneous materials.

por.por_cntn:
Heterogenous catalysis is at the center of many key industrial processes to produce building-block chemicals. With the growth of the world population, the demand for building-block chemicals increases dramatically. These processes performed at an industrial scale usually involve carbon- and energy-intensive operation, emitting a significant number of greenhouse gases, such as CO2. While some optimized catalysts can reduce energy consumption by lowering the temperature, minimizing the formation of undesired by-products such as CO2 remains one of the critical goals. Developing an efficient, selective, and cost-effective catalyst is urgently needed to sustain the growing world population. This topic is particularly urgent for those carbon- and energy-intensive operations, such as propylene production through propane dehydrogenation. In light of this, we aim to sustain propylene production by investigating the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane. The nature of ODH reaction to generate water can lower the intrinsic thermodynamic energy of the reaction, reducing energy input. Our group discovered that hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) and other boron-containing materials are highly selective ODH catalysts. In this project, we aim to gain a molecular-level understanding of supported boron ODH catalyst synthesis and apply that understanding to develop improved catalysts.

 

We have demonstrated that the active sites for ODH catalysis are amorphous boron oxide/hydroxide clusters. In contrast, the isolated boron sites are not ODH active. This knowledge was used to devise more cost-effective and efficient ODH catalysts. For example, we have developed a cost-effective ODH catalyst based on activated carbons and silica. In addition, this design rule of supported boron catalysts was revealed by a combination of research approaches including controlled synthesis based on the grafting method, a robust structure-activity relationship, and an advanced characterization based on solid-state NMR techniques. These approaches offer a set of techniques to realize the nature of active sites in heterogeneous catalysts. For example, the high-field solid-state NMR experiments demonstrated in this project may help to elucidate the nature of active sites containing quadrupolar isotopes. Taken together, the interdisciplinary expertise developed in the project shed light on heterogeneous catalysis. It may inspire new research approaches to improve a broad range of heterogeneously catalyzed reactions with poor selectivities.

 

This work is a foundation for further studies into these promising boron-containing ODH catalysts. In addition to contributions to catalysis science, this grant has funded the training of one female and one male graduate student. This grant has also allowed for the development and growth of academic collaborations with Professor Aaron Rossini at Iowa State University for solid-state NMR.
